noMisleadingInstantiator.description:
Description

Enforce proper usage ofnewandconstructor.
In JavaScript, classes utilize theconstructormethod to initialize a new instance. On the other hand, TypeScript interfaces can describe a class type with anew()method signature, though this pattern is not commonly seen in real-world code. Developers, especially those new to JavaScript or TypeScript, might occasionally confuse the use ofconstructorwithnew.
This rule triggers warnings in the following scenarios:
When a class has a method named new.
When an interface defines a method named constructor or new that returns the interface type.
When a type alias has a constructor method.
You should not use this rule if you intentionally want a class with anewmethod, and youâ€™re confident nobody working in your code will mistake it with anconstructor.
noMisleadingInstantiator.option: This rule has no specific options.
